exercises.title: Array Basics
exercises.description: Learn to create and manipulate arrays in JavaScript
exercises.readme:
# Exercise 4: Array Basics

Arrays are one of the most fundamental data structures in JavaScript. Let's learn how to work with them!

## Learning Objectives

- Understand what arrays are and why they're useful
- Create arrays using array literals
- Access array elements using indices
- Modify array elements
- Use the length property

## Instructions

Open the `exercise.js` file and complete the following functions:

1. `createFruitArray()` - Return an array containing three fruit names
2. `getFirstElement(arr)` - Return the first element of the given array
3. `getLastElement(arr)` - Return the last element using the length property
4. `addToEnd(arr, item)` - Add an item to the end of the array and return the array

## Requirements

- `createFruitArray()` must return an array with exactly 3 strings
- `getFirstElement()` should work with any array
- `getLastElement()` should work with arrays of any length
- `addToEnd()` should modify the original array

## Example

```javascript
const fruits = createFruitArray();
console.log(fruits); // ["apple", "banana", "orange"]

getFirstElement(fruits); // "apple"
getLastElement(fruits); // "orange"
addToEnd(fruits, "grape"); // ["apple", "banana", "orange", "grape"]
```

## Tips

- Array indices start at 0 (the first element is at index 0)
- Use `array.length` to get the number of elements
- The last element is at index `array.length - 1`
- The `push()` method adds elements to the end of an array

Good luck! ðŸŽ

exercises.title: Conditional Statements
exercises.description: Learn to make decisions in your code with if/else statements
exercises.readme:
# Exercise 5: Conditional Statements

Conditionals allow your code to make decisions and execute different code based on different conditions.

## Learning Objectives

- Understand how if/else statements work
- Use comparison operators (===, !==, <, >, <=, >=)
- Combine conditions with logical operators (&&, ||, !)
- Write else if chains for multiple conditions
- Use the ternary operator for simple conditions

## Instructions

Open the `exercise.js` file and complete the following functions:

1. `isAdult(age)` - Return true if age is 18 or older, false otherwise
2. `getGrade(score)` - Return letter grade (A, B, C, D, F) based on score
3. `canVote(age, isCitizen)` - Return true if person can vote (18+ AND citizen)
4. `maxOfTwo(a, b)` - Return the larger of two numbers

## Requirements

- `isAdult()`: 18 and above returns true, below 18 returns false
- `getGrade()`: A (90-100), B (80-89), C (70-79), D (60-69), F (0-59)
- `canVote()`: Must be 18+ AND a citizen to return true
- `maxOfTwo()`: Return the larger number, or either if equal

## Example

```javascript
isAdult(25); // true
isAdult(15); // false

getGrade(95); // "A"
getGrade(75); // "C"

canVote(20, true); // true
canVote(20, false); // false
canVote(16, true); // false

maxOfTwo(10, 5); // 10
maxOfTwo(3, 8); // 8
```

## Tips

- Use `===` for equality comparison (not `=` or `==`)
- The `&&` operator means AND (both conditions must be true)
- The `||` operator means OR (at least one condition must be true)
- Use `else if` for multiple conditions in sequence
- Consider using a ternary operator for simple true/false returns

Good luck! ðŸŽ¯
